qas.question: When did some madaris become considered like traditional colleges?
What class of people founded both European universities and Islamic madaris
What was considered to be the underlying purpose of madaris?
Who argued that European universities and Islamic madaris have very little in common?
When did some madaris become considered unlike traditional colleges?
What class of people founded only European universities?
What class of people founded only Islamic madaris?
What was considered to be the overt purpose of madaris?
Who agreed that European universities and Islamic madaris have very little in common?

context: There is disagreement whether madaris ever became universities. Scholars like Arnold H. Green and Seyyed Hossein Nasr have argued that starting in the <a0_0><b4_0>10th century<b4_0/><a0_0/>, some medieval Islamic madaris indeed became universities. <a3_0><b8_0>George Makdisi<b8_0/><a3_0/> and others, however, argue that the European university has no parallel in the medieval Islamic world. Darleen Pryds questions this view, pointing out that madaris and European universities in the Mediterranean region shared similar foundations by <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>princely patrons<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/> and were intended to provide loyal administrators to <a2_0><b7_0>further the rulers' agenda<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Other scholars regard the university as uniquely European in origin and characteristics.
